message:
Dear Geeks,
Please Don't miss this event , it will be great , I promise.
story: Asmaa Matar shared Mohammad Saad Omar's event to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Embedded Systems Track | IEEE AlexSB
caption: Embedded Systems Track | IEEE AlexSB
description:
IEEE AlexSB is pleased to announce the beginning of its first Track (series of seminars) this year, which will focus on Embedded Systems.

Embedded systems –in a very general sense– are simply systems that are responsible for controlling a certain process or a cluster of processes, which may vary in their complexity and overlapping. However, due to the electronics revolution that took over the world many decades ago, embedded systems now are computerized systems that mainly rely in its core on microprocessors or microcontrollers to organize and synchronize the execution of the processes they are in control of.

Embedded systems not only employ microprocessors to manipulate digital data, but also employ many peripherals and sensors that can interact with the physical world and implement physical quantities digitally so it would be more suitable for the operation of the microprocessors; these peripherals and sensors are digitally interfaced with the controllers and communicate with them via standard protocols like RS-232, SPI, I2C (I squared C)…and many more.
Many devices and instruments that we use in our daily lives rely in their operation on embedded systems, such as: airplanes, cars, microwaves, digital watches, mobile phones, and air conditioning systems.

--

The first session of our Embedded Systems Track will focus on two main topics; “The Internet of Things” (IOT), and The ARM Processors Architecture.

The Internet of Things (in a nutshell):
The term “Internet of Things” refers to uniquely identifiable objects and their virtual representations in an Internet-like structure. It simply aims to create a vast network structure like the internet, in which objects, buildings, services, means of transportation, and even people, would be interconnected and can communicate with each other, and everything connected to this network would have a unique identity. This will allow for an easier and faster exchange of information, and will facilitate and organize many of our everyday activities.

ARM Processors Architecture (in a nutshell):
ARM is the abbreviation of “Advanced RISC Machine”. It is a family of instruction set architectures for microprocessors, which is based on the reduced instruction set computing (RISC) developed by the British company ARM Holdings.
ARM processors are widely used in a variety of products and devices, such as smartphones, tablets, digital cameras…and a lot more.
For more information about ARM Processors, please visit this link: http://goo.gl/rpaZXT  



Here’s the main outline of the session:

• What is “The Internet of Things”?
• What is meant by “Embedded Systems”?
• Introduction to the basics of Embedded Systems Engineering.
• What is ARM.
• ARM Market Share and Applications.
• ARM Products and families.
• Arm Design Philosophy.
• Arm Technologies.
• Embedded System Hardware.
• Embedded System Software.
• ARM Core Developer Guide.

--

Session Date: Sunday 13th of April, 2014.

Session Time: 3:00pm to 5:00pm.

Session Place: Classroom (104), ground floor, Electrical Engineering Building, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University.

--

About the speaker: Mr. Mahmoud Sayed

Mr. Mahmoud Sayed received his Bachelor’s degree in Electronics and Communications Engineering In 2009 from Cairo University. 
He is currently working as a Business Development Manager at PiTechnologies Inc. 
Mr. Mahmoud is also the technical instructor for Embedded System Development Track at the Faculty of Computer and Information (FCI) at Cairo University, and also at Ain Shams University.
Mr. Mahmoud worked as a supervisor on a number of projects in the field of embedded systems such as: the Simulation of HSDPA/HSUPA Protocol (High Speed Downlink/Uplink Packet Access), the Simulation and implementation of ZIGBEE Protocol 802.15.4-20, and Objects monitoring through sensor-networks nodes.
Prior to his current position, Mahmoud worked as a Senior Software Engineer at PiTechnologies.
